Customize to generate a model of a cogwheel.
More flexible than http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:525490/.

update the module calling functions at the bottom lines as necessary:
cogwheel(numTeeth=30, r=14.53/2, r2=16.61/2, topLandWidth=0.2, spaceWidth=0.2, depth=1.45, cutout_radius=1.85/2);
numTeeth is the number of teeth.
r is the inner radius (at bottom land)
r2 is the outer radius (at top land)
top land width is the width of the tip of the teeth.
space width is the width of the bottom teeth.
depth is the thickness of the cogwheel.
cutout radius is the radius of the hole in the middle.
update the parameters as necessary.

title: MotorPixie Mini - Gimbal for the RCExplorer Tricopter V3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mini gimbal that mounts onto a custom camera plate for the RCExplorer Tricopter V3. Get the frame or directions how to build the tricopter frame here: http://www.RCExplorer.se
Some parts (camera plate, wire plates) are derived from David Windeståls brilliant designs. Find them all at RCExplorer.se
The finished gimbal weighs about 130g. A total of 200g with the GoPro Hero 3 mounted. To counter this "massive" weight, it is necessary to shift the battery to the back to balance the tricopter perfectly. Some test footage: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BfNrB5eJCtg

Quick assembly: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9lag_PZlVZE To complete this build you will need:
The 1.5mm piano wire dampeners from RCExplorer.se
(http://rcexplorer.se/product/pre-bent-vibration-dampening-wire/)
2x Turnigy 2804-210Kv Brushless Gimbal Motor
(http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=53932)
2-Axis brushless gimbal controller, preferably Mini Alexmos 2-axis Brushless Gimbal Controller BGC V2.2 DRV8313 Motor Driver
8x M2x6 hex screws
8x M2 washers
4x M3x6 hex screws
4x M3x10 hex screws
6x M3x16 hex screws
6x M3 nuts
Thick CA glue
For FPV: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idproduct=55297
Print all parts except for the camera tray (only included for reference). Make the camera tray using the PDF template. Cut it from a 3mm piece of plywood or 1.5 mm piece of G10 fiber glass or carbon fiber.
The wire plates go under the camera plate to fix the piano wires in place. Use the pilot holes to line up the wire plates with the camera plate.

I am an overzealous, inexperienced pilot with a propensity for landward travel. I broke my mounts badly enough that I needed replacements - so I turned to my printer! If you have an issues or improvements, please let me know.

PLA
So far I've made (and broken) many of these in PLA. That stuff is super brittle and can't really take much of a hit. PLA works great if you're experienced and don't make many rough landings. 100% infill seems better than less than 100%. Nylon
Tricky to print with - so far hasn't broken, but I haven't crashed too badly with it. Way more flex than the PLA or glass fiber (stock material), but it seems to fly fine. Might make some changes to increase rigidity. Please be careful as these haven't been through much testing. Attach as you would normal mounts.

This band is designed to fit a men's Skagen watch, but the same concept could be used for any watch. The Ninjaflex material is flexible enough that it can stretch over your hand. One piece is faster, simpler, and provides lots of room for custom designs. http://www.ninjaflex3d.com/products/ninjaflex-filaments/

author: kknust

description.text:
Yavuz Demirhan is a prolific Turkish puzzle inventor with nearly150 published designs at Puzzle Will Be Played ( http://puzzlewillbeplayed.com/-/designer/Demirhan.xml ).
Tetradyma is one of his latest and is unusual in that it requires four identical pieces to fit into a cube shape. It is also printable without needing any support material.
I would rate it as tricky but not difficult - a great design to give to novice puzzlers.

The model includes a 0.1 mm offset and is based on 8 mm unit cubes. Although it could be scaled, be aware that this will change the tolerances and will affect how well the pieces fit together.
I printed mine in PLA using 0.2 mm layer height, 0.4 mm extrusion width and 40% infill. I used Slic3r 0.98 and printed all 4 copies at the same time, using the More button.

Hello there, 
This is my first addition to the Thingiverse and the first time I've ever used Openscad. So please let me know if there is any mistakes made, either in the code or the upload in general. 
It's supposed to be a basic customizable gear, that can be used in any situation as a replacement gear. I wanted to give the user complete control over the different parameters to successfully be able to mimic their old gear. It may not be a involute gear, but it should suffice in most cases and therefore be a very USEFUL thing.  
Anyhow, it's been fun to make, and it's always fun to learn some new things. I'm usually a 3dsmax/vray/inventor man but I'am a sucker for everything open source.

description.text:
I've modified my derivative filament spindle design to accommodate for slightly thicker 1/4" acrylic and made some modifications to reduce the likelihood of "binary failures" including this modification for reducing stress on the t-slots (thanks to tinkerings for pointing this out to me):
http://blog.ponoko.com/2010/06/17/how-to-make-snug-joints-in-acrylic/

Same overall construction as the last spindle except that you'll now have to use 20mm or longer bolts to install the pieces that hold the M5 nut in place. See it in action here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5zYvhdOi5wg#t=12m26s Kits available here:
http://builttospecstore.storenvy.com/products/48101-crystal-filament-spindle-v1-1-kit

Fits 1 (one)  Maxbotix LV-EZx in a 3x2x4 Brick.  This mount is intended to basically hold up a MaxSonar LV-EZ0 Range Finder Sonar for prototyping some ideas.
The brick itself is equal to 3 (2x4) Lego bricks. So it can be "bricked" into a nice support structure to hold it in place.
A huge help when you are trying to make something and don't want your sensors out and loose. That can cause shorts, pulled wires, and or just slow you down.
It should be compatible with All "EZ" series.

• Print it Face Down.

  • In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings:
    Quality: Layer Height = 0.16
    • All other defaults are the same. If you don't have a 3D printer we can make you one pretty cheap.. Visit: badbrick.com/catalog

description.text:
Enclosed case for Ramps 1.4 3D controller board. Mounting holes are 103 MM apart and 6 MM wide. It is a very tight fit for the Ramps board, the top mounting hole (the side with the small hole) also does not align with the mounting hole on the board, but the bottom two do.
The lid is designed to fit a 50 MM fan, if you want to place it inside the case it must be a thin one, but originally I planned on having the fan outside the case.

• The Case
    Print at what ever layer height you want. The screw holes for the lid needs support, but only if printed in the orientation in .stl file. It may not need it, if you can rotate it.
    Mounting holes for case are the two 6 MM holes on the side, they are 103 MM apart. Mounting holes for Ramps 1.4 board are 2 MM. The top Ramps mounting hole does not align with board. Use bottom two.

  • The Lid
    Print at what ever layer height you want. No support needed. Fan can be mounted on either side of lid.

  • Fan Cover
    Prints OK at .2 MM layer height. Would probably look best at .1 MM layer height. No support needed.

title: Xole FatShark attitude V2 camera and transmitter mount (TVL 600, 250mw Tx)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I know, I have a head tracker. But in the mean time I made an adjustable mount so you can play with fixed angles of the camera. Works with TVL 600, and other cameras of same demensions. Holds the 250mw transmitter so the electronics are not touching anything, and air can flow freely around. I printed mine in t-glase, no support, 1mm shell with 20% infill. Be careful sliding in transmitter as you don't want to damage the heatshrink. Took me 4 tries to get it just right.
This mount can be upsidedown as well, or backwards if you want the camera pointing up. May work out to be a second camera for me.

title: Pool vacuum wheel pin/shaft and retainer ring

description.text: My brother has a pool vacuum that has several wheels held in place by two part clips. They keep breaking.  It's a salt water pool.  Replacements cost something like $15 for four of them.  Being a captive market, they can get away with it.  Not any more, I designed a replacement pin and retainer ring for him.

I printed it vertically with the flat end down with 25% fill and a raft.  You can also do it without a raft.  Print one of these and one retaining ring and snap them together on either side of the pool vacuum wheel.  THEY WORK!!!  SEE THE PHOTO.
It is 34mm tall (1.338") and fits a wheel with a 9mm center shaft (approx. 11/32")
I will add the type of vacuum once I get the name.
You should be able to gang up multiples of each part with Makerware and print a set at a time.  I printed the first ones in yellow so we could ID them on his vacuum and see how long they last.

title: i3 Adjustable Z-Axis Micro Endstop for 8mm Smooth Rod

description.text:
Designed for the microswitch mechanical endstop. If you are using Aluminum Couplers on your Z-Axis, I'm not totally certain if it will not rub the side of your coupler. I did try to make the endstop holder as thin as possible. What I used:

author: Photog

description.text:
This thing contains the parts necessary to print a three-quarter scale version of the Electric Parametric Violin (Revision 2). This violin was designed in Solidworks 2012 as part of a parametric model that generates any necessary size of violin. If you would like CAD files, you can find them here. This set of instruments is my third attempt at electric violin design - the first is a 1/2 scale model for my daughter. The second was a 1/16 scale model for my son.
As with the last design, this violin's roots can be found in the excellent FFFiddle by David Perry

description.header: A full range of EPV sizes are available:
description.text:
4/4 Scale
3/4 Scale
1/2 Scale
1/4 Scale
1/8 Scale
1/16 Scale

• See the instructions document for detailed build instructions.
  • Split versions of large parts are included for use on smaller printers.
  • I printed all parts with raft, 15% infill, 4 shells.
  • The fingerboard should be printed without support since it is difficult to remove from the long holes in the part. (If you do want to print this with support, you can use a piece of music wire with a bend in the end and a drill to clean it out.)
  • I used ABS, but any stiff polymer should be acceptable.

    Additional components required:

  • Schaller M6 Mini tuners (3+3)
  • K&K sound "Twin spot" piezoelectric pickup
  • 1/4" rod or tube (tube is preferred - rod will need to have a hole drilled in it)
  • Violin strings
  • 20" of music wire (0.025" - 0.035" diameter - alternatively, a ball-end violin string can be used)

    Tools:

  • Hacksaw - use this to put a slot in the end of the tube that will catch the knot in the end of the music wire
  • Small Phillips Screwdriver - for driving tuner screws
  • A variety of grits of sandpaper - used to smooth the surface of the fingerboard. A small amount of the appropriate solvent helps too.
  • 10 mm wrench - for tightening the tuner banjo nuts.
  • A triangular or knife-edge file - for making notches in the bridge and nut for strings. With care, a sharp knife can be used for this.
  • Appropriate tools for cleaning support material from prints

This thing contains the parts necessary to print a one-half scale version of the Electric Parametric Violin (Revision 2). This violin was designed in Solidworks 2012 as part of a parametric model that generates any necessary size of violin. If you would like CAD files, you can find them here. UPDATE: I've added split parts for smaller printers. See the instructions below for more details. This set of instruments is my third attempt at electric violin design - the first is a 1/2 scale model for my daughter. The second was a 1/16 scale model for my son.
As with the last design, this violin's roots can be found in the excellent FFFiddle by David Perry

description.header: A full range of EPV sizes are available:
description.text:
4/4 Scale
3/4 Scale
1/2 Scale
1/4 Scale
1/8 Scale
1/16 Scale

• See the instructions document for detailed build instructions.
  • Split versions of large parts are included for use on smaller printers.
  • I printed all parts with raft, 15% infill, 4 shells.
  • The fingerboard should be printed without support since it is difficult to remove from the long holes in the part. (If you do want to print this with support, you can use a piece of music wire with a bend in the end and a drill to clean it out.)
  • I used ABS, but any stiff polymer should be acceptable.

I've had a couple of requests to update this model for printers with a smaller bed. The A and B variants of the body and the fingerboard are split parts. When building with split parts, I recommend the following steps:
  • Sand the joining surfaces
  • Use an adhesive appropriate for the material being joined (I generally recommend epoxy, but YMMV)
  • Assemble the parts
    .. For the body, use 1/8" diameter dowel pins that are one inch long to provide a mechanical connection between parts.
    ..     For the fingerboard, I recommend assembling the parts on the truss rod (with tensioning wire fully assembled), then assembling the violin. The tension of the assembled parts will clamp the joint together.

edit: I updated this so that it uses less plastic to print. Newest one is the noncrustable. I just took measurements of the cheap $1 loaf of bread and created this because it creates less waste compared the circular one(and bigger sandwiches!!). You can throw the waste in the compost or give it to your cat, whatever works for you.
A little bit of sandwich science for you... The average loaf of bread is 4"x4", I made this 93mmx93mm(3.66"). It cuts the crust off perfectly, just be careful when lining it up to cut it. Make sure you press the cutting part down hard. Microwave the top piece of bread for a couple of seconds if it is old or it could crack open when you seal the sandwich.
I recommend putting the PBJ into the refrigerator to get them cold prior to inhaling them. :)
See printing instructions for configuration.
I recommend 20% infill, 1 perimeter, 2 solid layers bottom and top, detect thin walls, more perimeters if needed.

Update 23. November 2014:
I extended the bottom angled part of the front skids. No matter how I tried to print them, they always ended up curling and producing an extremely ugly angled edge when using ABS. Should be much cleaner to print now, but there'll still be minor curling at the back of the two rails inside. Cut with a skalpel.

Update 21. November 2014:
Finally had a chance to do a proper maiden flight and film it.
http://youtu.be/CelgFdRE9Kc

Update 19. November 2014:
Modified the buzzer plug hole position some to fit the plug better.

Update 16. November 2014:
  • I modified the landing skids a little to include slots for 2.5mm wide zip ties, to avoid them having a chance to slip off. Print as-is, with support and overhang angle at 30°.
  • I also updated the tail. The nut trap was still too large for my taste, introducing quite some play and also allowing the nut to turn when trying to tighten it down. The new nut trap is properly sized for M3 nuts, but can be a bit tight. My slicer added support inside the hole, I had to clear some bits with a sharp knife. If you have trouble getting the nut to fit, stick a long M3 screw in from the back of the tail, screw it a few turns into the nut, then pull the nut into the opening firmly.
  • Modified the canopy. Shorter at the rear, reduced the hole at the back. Slightly increased width of the ziptie slots to reduce rubbing.

    I made some modifications to this awesome design by Boxx to better suit my setup.
    The inside space was widened and standoffs were put in place so a KK Mini board (30.5x30.5mm mounting points) could be installed. I used metal screws to thread the holes, then used nylon screws to fix the KK in place. Since I had no 3mm nylon screws, I used 8mm ones and cut them off at the bottom.
    The motor mounts were modified to allow me to mount motors with a flat bottom and 2x12+2x16mm motor mounting holes for M2 screws, such as the DYS BE1806 motors. You can still use 4x12mm motors, just with 2 screws instead.. that is still plenty of support. Use washers.
    A 3mm hole was added to the front to allow the installation of a 3mm LED. In my print, it fits snugly with a little push, but you may have to add a drop of hotglue to keep it in place. You can grab 5V for the LED (with a proper resistor) from the ISP port at the front of the KK board for a little less wiring mess.
    I added a hole for the buzzer plug, but I have no idea if it fits.. I have my buzzer directly soldered to the board. If anyone tests this, let me know please. I uploaded both versions with and without the buzzer plug hole.
    The tail was changed to open up one side to allow the installation of the motor without having to desolder the wires and lead them through the hole. Also, with the 1806, this was a tight fit in the first place due to the thicker wires they use. I modified the nut trap a bit, as it was so wide that the nyloc nut started spinning when trying to tighten the tail bolt. Lastly, the tail was modified to be laid flat on the bed, allowing for cleaner printing of the bottom and top and without needing any support.
    The canopy had to be redesigned. Admittedly, this is a bit of a hack job.. I've never used any CAD-like software before and this is the best that I could do. It has two slots for zipties that will at the same time secure the ESC power wires of the two front ESCs if mounted as intended.
    I wired the servo and ESCs to lower profile pinheader sockets to reduce the required height as much as possible. However, I still use a full size servo plug for the OrangeRX satellite, so I assume the canopy will fit with standard plugs too.
    There is a theoretical space for a 3x7x3 bearing on both sides of the tail. The inner one was already there in the original, but ended up being a little too small on my print. The one on the outside is just meant to give the bearing some hold. If they are tight, try adding metal washers on either side.
    If you find any problems, let me know and I can try to fix them.

Modified in Sketchup, printed in ABS with 40% infill. AUW with 3S is
~300g.
Using DYS BE1806 motors, HQProp 5040 carbon mix propellers, HK Blueseries 12A ESCs with SimonK firmware, KK2 Mini, OrangeRX Spektrum Satellite.
I used Cura to slice at 0.2mm for my Mendel90.
Tail may need minor support, front skids will need support. Print all parts as-is, front skids with support for 30° overhangs.

comments.text: My first build snapped in half behind the front arms. I just finished rebuilding with a new plate scaled to 2.5x in the z axis and it seems VERY strong now.
comments.author: Gyrobot

comments.text: Indeed, I was looking for a combination of your solid plate and plate with ribs and slots so I put the two together and then added the aluminum to make it even stronger. Thanks for the great design work by the way!
comments.author: Gyrobot

comments.text: The orientation of your infill means that every other layer is parallel to the line along which it snapped. Try rotating the infill direction by an extra 45deg. Also the triangle infill pattern in the Craftware slicer makes for a stronger part.
comments.author: wpmfield

comments.text: Also the stringy consistency of his infill indicates that the extruder temp may have been a bit too low.
comments.author: Gyrobot

comments.text: That's an excellent idea! I'll give it a try. I haven't delved into the infill rotation or using a pattern other than hex. It will be nice to prevent/reduce this parallel snapping on some of my other designs.
comments.author: Gyrobot

description.text: This helps stabilize your iphone5 when you are using the 30pin to lightning adapter.

Ever feel uncomfortable when your iphone 5 has very little holding it in place during the use of the 30 pin to Lightning adapter? This is the missing piece of plastic the adds stability to the iphone 5 when using the adapter
After printing you have to remove the .8 mm piece of plastic that is in the way of where the phone goes. The thin wall of plastic is for support while printing. It removes easily with a razor cutter especially if you can cut the middle first. Sorry about this part but it makes for a good print.
It is a pretty tight fit when you put the adapter into the plastic piece. Once it is in I don't worry about it coming out.
Depending on your print tighten with tape or file a little out till it fits tight.

title: Aligned Normals are a Good Thing

description.text:
Thingiverse has some really awesome 3D models that are printable on 3D Printers! However, not all of these great models have STL files that are correct. This is the equivalent of posting a part that is described in it's STL file like everything is in side out! Not fun! It can work on some 3D Printers - but not all - and after all one big goal of Thingiverse is sharing - "Share and Enjoy!". The Good News: There are several freely available ways to fix these STL files! Look at the two images at the right: Both are prints from the UP! Both Pictures contain a broken and a fixed STL file print, the one is right off the printer - the other is after removing the support material.
Note that the broken part printed the bottom of the part in a hollow criss-cross pattern instead of being solid

1) Netfabbs cloud http://cloud.netfabb.com/ - you can upload your STL part and netfabb will repair it and let you download it and send a copy to your email address 2) Applications
Meshlab (credit nicholasclewis) http://meshlab.sourceforge.net/ - One of its many filters is "Re-orient all faces coherently". Meshlab is very nice open source, portable app.
AccuTrans3d: http://www.micromouse.ca/downloads.html - very powerful but somewhat manual process 3) Other Comment on this thing with your favorite way to repair STL files. netfabb and others have software can repair STLs in manual, semi-manual, or automatic ways. I am not being paid or coerced to advocate for netfabb or MicroMouse/AccuTrans3d or PP3DP - the UP! company

title: Inmoov Hand Jr Servo Pulley (8g/9g servo)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the servo pulley I ended up making for my version of the Inmoov Robot, the Inmoov Jr. This will fit the Tower pro blue 8g or 9g servos and the MG90s servos - but the MG90 will not fit in the servo bed - a new one is needed which im working on. Please read instructions if you want to build a an Inmoov Jr, its pretty simple.
Printed mine all in ABS, I found it easier for the finer detail parts as they stay nice and flat on top when printing and dont need a cooling fan.

Some time back I told Hairy that I was making a mini version, I'm sure he chuckled a little inside because of how fiddly it can be - especially when you shrink things down. If you want to build an Inmoov Jr I will be posting all the modified parts, but I'll be honest - there isn't many needed.
After many tests, I found the absolute best thing to do was just scale ALL of Hairy's inmoov parts down to 64%. So, thats all I did. I re-scaled the entire hand, wrist and forearm assembly down to 64% before I printed them and that seemed to be the magic number before things started to get messy (like small threading holes etc)
I used 8g serv's because they were spares, I recommend 9g servos but the tower pro metal geared mg-90s will not fit in the servo bed, I am working on the new bracket.

title: Garmin Edge 500, 510, 800 ,810 Mount with 3 versions to choose from
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Handlebar mount for your Garmen edge 500/510, 800/810 using a 1/4 turn to lock it in place.  There are three versions, one with a solid arm, one with a spider arm, and for those that have strenght issues with prints one that utilises the original Garmin bar mount that comes with the unit.  The Garmin mount sits inside the 3D printed one and is held in place by a bottom cap.  Also included is an adapter for thinner handlbars.  Remeber you will need to print 2 of these.  
All you need is an M5 nut and bolt to finish it off and a 3mm diameter metal pin for the clamp pivot.   
Thumb screw means you can easily adjust the poistion of the mount or remove for mounting to another bike without needing tools.

I print these on their side so the layers run around the bar at right angles to give more strength.
.
You may need to lightly sand the face that contacts the back or your Garmen as the printed layers may stand out a fraction and cause friction. If this happens sanding will ensure a smooth twist and lock.
.
If using the mount that utilises the orginal Gamin mount place the mount into the 3D printed part and secure it in place by glueing the ring into the recess as per the pictures
.

comments.text: I was wondering how well this would hold up on a mountain bike.  I definitely will be doing a lot of downhill with my Garmin edge 500 along with long cross country rides.  I have a similar shaped metal mount on my road bike that I could swap out to my road bike if I have to, but I hope I won't need to.
comments.author: surfaspen

comments.text: So far my experience is the road bike has been far more harsh on the mount due to the high tire pressures and no suspension.     The lower pressure tires and suspension on the mountain bike has meant very little stress on the mount.
comments.author: surfaspen

comments.text: Thanks for the quick reply.  I thought about the vibrations with and without suspension.  But on my mountain bike, there is definitely more vibrations on many of the trails I do.  For example, I rode a trail near my house today that was mainly downhill shale rock and it was almost hard to hold on when letting off of the brakes.  The vibrations on my road bike might be more immediate, but the vibrations from the mountain bike are surely larger.  Maybe adding a layer of electrical tape to the inside of the clamp might let it grip better.
comments.author: d3delta3d

comments.text: Interesting.  Grip wise I have found once the mount is locked on the bar I cannot move it without first loosening it off which is a good thing.

comments.text: Hi mate .  I printed the part on my up mini in the orientation the thing files are shown above, so standing on it's side.  I used 0.2 layer thickness, 240ºc extruder temp and the standard support and had no issues.   I can say however that when printing with the red ABS  filament the support comes off really really easy.  If I use blue filament of the same brand the support is near impossible to get off in places.  Pretty much have to cut it off which either makes or breaks the print.

Warp Nacelle for the NCC 1701 D (Enterprise D) from the Ed WHitefire blueprints.

Here are two additional componenets and an updated Nacelle body. The 1mm holes in the bussard Collector are for 1mm rod for proper alignment with the body end cap. You will need 2 Nacelle bodies. This provides for a 2mm garp for clear palstic sheeting that can be used for the subspace field vector array. 
02/28/13 - Updated the Bussard Collector and added the Warp Nacelle End piece.
03/01/13 - Added the right and left nacelle struts. I will produce a new lower nacelle body and add connection holes between the struts and the nacelle body soon.I am currently working on the design for Deck 36 which will include conduits for wiring or Fiber optic lighting as well as the battery slots of Li-Ion batteries.
03/02/13 - Added the beginning of Deck 36 and updated the Lower Nacelle body and the left and right struts for connecting holes.
I would be happy to hear any comments so I can improve the design. Hopefully soon I can get my 3D printer up and running so I can try a print myself.

description.text: Drag Chain w/ STL's fixed via netfabb cloud. Please see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5443 for a discussion of fixing STLs. All real credit goes to Zaggo. This is a drag chain for the MakerBot extruder cable (or any other cable/wires). It keeps your extruder cable out of the Z-stage belt and let your MakerBot look professional (kind of...) The objects need very detailed printing in order to work. You definitely want a good tuned MakerBot and Skeinforge settings to print this (don't say I didn't warn you!). The ZIP file contains GCode files for all objects, including 6 or 8 chain links on one raft. It might be the best to skeinforge the gcode with your own, tuned settings. The included GCode files worked for me (resp. my MakerBot), but (again): these are some really hairy objects to print.

• Print as many chain links as you need or like. For the extruder cable on my Makerbot I use 12 links.
  • If you insert a standard patch cable (like the extruder cable which came with the MakerBot batch 5 kits), you shouldn't need any additional closing mechanism. If you insert only a few wires, print out one or more "Closing Sticks". Cut the stick into pieces and use the notch in the chain links to hold the wires inside the chain.
  • If your extruder cable is mounted upright (default, when using the MK3 Plastruder), you sholdn't need any special end link. If your extruder driver card is mounted horizontal (like mine in the photos), print the optional "End Corner Extruder" piece. Use this piece as last link on the extruder side and tape it to the RJ45 jack (see photo). Clip the flat part if needed.
  • To mount the drag chain to the MakerBot body (or elsewhere), print the "Chain Anchor" piece. It has holes for using the upper Z endstop bolts to mount it to the outside of the body. Then just use the notch on the last chain link to attach the drag chain to the anchor.

description.text:
Spherical shaped drinking glass designed for single shell corkscrew printing with T-glase filament. Fits well in the hand, nice interference finish, lightweight but perfectly water tight. The shell is only 0.5mm but still robust!
Material cost is about 0.5€.

There are two models, one non-closed surface and one solid object. The open surface works fine in Simplify3D, don't know about other slicing software. If you have problems, then use the solid object and cancel the print before it starting to fill the upper surface.
Tested with Wanhao Duplicator 4x with 1.75mm T-glase filament. Used glass plate with painter´s tape.
Sliced with Simplify3D (unit: mm):
Layer height: 0.37mm
Bottom layers: 3
Shells: 1 one corkscrew vase mode
Temp: Extruder=235C, board=80C
Speed: 650mm/min
Extrusion multiplier: 1.15
Extrusion width: 0.5mm
try
Yet another . . .  This is the piece that replaces the one in the car I used for the Iphone 4. It is light but sturdy enough.

Print and fit the lightning adapter in place. It is a tight fit but depending on your print use tape or file so the adapter stays in place while you move the phone in and out.
There is a hole for the headphone jack. Unfortunately it is only a hole since the plastic around the jacks come in different sizes.

title: Classic Crosley Record Player - Ghostly Plate

description.text:
Another Maker Challenge Entry. I always liked old timey kind of items and making them into use able objects for current times. My friend took one of these and changed it into a computer case. this version is't as flashy but figured it make a nice item to anyone's collection.
.
I may detail it out later and make a face plate that is more accurate to the actual Crosely record player.
.
Edit: Fixed the orientation of the files. You will still need to scale them but they should import properly.
.
Also added a version with drawers so its more than just a large piece of plastic. it can be used as a storage box on top of just a neat decorative item

This is scaled up to pretty much full size. you may need to scale it down to fit the parts into most printers.
Also note for whatever reason my software won't allow me to set the origin when If printing the one with no drawers you will need:
(1) Record Player - Arm

(1) Record Player Lid
(1) Record Player Face Plate
(2) Record Player Face Plate Peg

(1) Record If printing the one with drawers you will need:

Wall Partition Divider Caps for Work
Do you have an air gap by your sink that dumps water all over the counter whenever you run your dishwasher?  The idea behind this part is to prevent this from happening to you.

Simply measure your air gap shroud and set the clip_id variable to this value.  This alone might be good enough to get you going.  Then print and clip this around the shroud.  The walls keep the water contained, and the base will allow the water to flow into your sink, instead of on your countertop.  You can adjust the length of the walls in case your air gap is far away from the sink -- just change the variable trough_length.  You can even play with the rear clip opening, as well as the angle of the walls!

comments.text: I'll do it when I get home today.  :)  The air gap is the think that sticks out of your sink, and prevents water from flowing back from the drain to your dishwasher.  When your dishwasher runs, water will get directed out the air gap and shoot into your sink.  However, if your air gap shroud isn't placed well enough (or fitted properly), it could shoot water all over your sink.  This part is intended to capture the water and help direct it into the sink.

title: Album wall hangers inspired by GHOSTLY INTERNATIONAL

description.text: Why keep your albums on a shelf when you can hang them up for all to appreciate? Display the album artwork with these themed wall hangers inspired by Ghostly International.

Print face up using supports under the Ghoslty International Logos. The larger part supports the bottom of the album and the smaller part retains the top of the album. Use small drywall nails or pins through the ghost-shaped holes to fasten. Enjoy!

title: Razer Naga Epic Dock & Cord Keeper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
If you own a Naga Epic and you're like me, you gave up on using it wirelessly. I never remember to put it in the dock to charge. I'm forced to use the mouse in a wired configuration, and this leaves the cord free to dangle off of my desk.
This little fella gives the rarely-used charging station a home, and acts as a cord keeper... all in one neat little package.

1) Print.
2) Insert cord into slot in bottom.
3) Place charging station on top.
